properties.Title: Special Weather Statement In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: A low pressure system currently over northern Saskatchewan will push inclement weather into the Kivalliq over the next couple of days. Rain and strong easterly winds moved into Arviat this afternoon. Wet snow will move into Rankin and Chesterfield Inlet this evening before transitioning to rain overnight. As well, winds will increase overnight with gusts in excess of 80 km/h expected. These strong winds will gradually diminish Monday evening. The rain will persist through to Tuesday. For Baker Lake, the precipitation will move into the community as wet snow this evening, with gusty easterly winds strengthening overnight. Surface temperatures will be mild, but snow may be coming down heavily at times, so it is likely to accumulate on the ground. Accumulations up to 10 cm is possible by Monday afternoon. Along with the snow, on Monday, winds will increase with gusts up to 80 km/h. The precipitation will transition to rain by Monday evening and winds will gradually diminish. Monday afternoon, snow associated with this system will move into Coral Harbour and Naujaat. Snow will persist through Monday night with accumulations of 5 to 10 cm possible. Temperatures will slowly warm overnight on Monday, and precipitation will transition to rain for Tuesday. Along with the snow and rain, southeasterly winds gusting up to 80 km/h will impact Coral Harbour and Naujaat Monday night and through Tuesday. Winds and precipitation will gradually taper off overnight on Tuesday. Please refer to the public forecast for more details and stay alert for any warning bulletins issued for your community. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NUstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NUStorm.
Expires: 2020-10-12T11:37:40-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2020-10-11T19:38:40-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.1715275799.2020
Area: Baker Lake, Arviat, Rankin Region including Whale Cove, Chesterfield Inlet, Naujaat, Coral Harbour
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Special Weather Statement In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Rain at times heavy Monday and Monday night. A low pressure system will bring rain at times heavy to regions along the north shore of Lake Superior beginning Monday morning. General rainfall amounts are expected to be 20 to 30 mm. However, it is possible that some localized areas could receive up to 50 mm by Tuesday morning. Localized flooding is possible. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to ONstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #ONStorm.
Expires: 2020-10-12T14:39:54-00:00

properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Special Weather Statement In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: A low pressure system currently over Saskatchewan will track northeastward toward southern Kivalliq over the next couple of days. Rain and easterly winds gusting up to 80 km/h will move into Arviat, Rankin Inlet and Chesterfield Inlet beginning this evening. These strong winds will gradually diminish Monday evening. The rain will persist through to Tuesday. For Baker Lake, the precipitation will move into the community as wet snow beginning this evening, with gusty easterly winds strengthening overnight. Surface temperatures will be mild, but snow may be coming down heavily at times, so it is likely to accumulate on the ground. Heaviest accumulations are expected on Monday with up to 10 cm possible by Monday evening. Along with the snow, on Monday, winds will increase with gusts up to 70 km/h. The precipitation will transition to rain by Tuesday morning and winds will gradually diminish. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NUstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NUStorm.
Expires: 2020-10-12T06:18:20-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2020-10-11T14:19:20-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.3064254766.2020
Area: Baker Lake, Arviat, Rankin Region including Whale Cove, Chesterfield Inlet
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Special Weather Statement In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Strong winds this afternoon and tonight A low pressure centre is approaching Vancouver Island this morning. The low will move right over Victoria late this evening and then quickly move through the Lower Mainland overnight. This afternoon, southeast winds will increase to 50 km/h gusting to 70 over communities near Georgia and Haro Strait, with southeast winds of 60 km/h gusting to 80 over exposed sections of West Vancouver Island. Behind the low overnight, winds will shift to west 50 km/h gusting to 70 to 80. The westerlies will ease Monday morning. Currently, the track and depth of the low suggest wind speeds will stay just below warning thresholds but some power outages are still likely. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to BCstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #BCStorm.
Expires: 2020-10-12T08:08:52-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2020-10-11T16:09:52-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.0657350435.2020
Area: East Vancouver Island - Duncan to Nanaimo, East Vancouver Island - Nanoose Bay to Fanny Bay, East Vancouver Island - Courtenay to Campbell River, West Vancouver Island, Greater Victoria, Sunshine Coast - Gibsons to Earls Cove, Sunshine Coast - Saltery Bay to Powell River, Metro Vancouver - North Shore including West Vancouver and North Vancouver, Metro Vancouver - central including the City of Vancouver Burnaby and New Westminster, Metro Vancouver - northeast including Coquitlam and Maple Ridge, Metro Vancouver - southeast including Surrey and Langley, Metro Vancouver - southwest including Richmond and Delta, Southern Gulf Islands
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Special Weather Statement In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Snowfall tonight and Thanksgiving Monday night. A series of fast moving frontal systems will move through southern BC tonight and tomorrow night. These systems will usher in colder air which will cause snow levels to fall to near 1300m overnight. For Allison Pass (Hope to Princeton): Up to 5cm of wet snow is possible tonight and an additional 5 to 10cm will fall Monday night. For Coquihalla Summit (Hope to Merritt): Up to 5cm of wet snow is possible overnight/early Monday morning. Another 5 to 10cm is possible Monday night. For Surrey Summit (Merritt to Kamloops): 5cm of snowfall tonight and 5cm again Monday night. For Rogers Pass (Revelstoke to Golden): 5cm of snow tonight/Monday morning and possibly more than 10cm on Tuesday. ### Weather in the mountains can change suddenly resulting in hazardous driving conditions. Road conditions are available at www.drivebc.ca. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to BCstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #BCStorm.
Expires: 2020-10-12T14:00:03-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2020-10-11T22:01:03-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.3438083364.2020
Area: Highway 3 - Hope to Princeton via Allison Pass, Coquihalla Highway - Hope to Merritt, Coquihalla Highway - Merritt to Kamloops, Trans-Canada Highway - Eagle Pass to Rogers Pass
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Winter Storm Watch In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: A strong low pressure system is expected to impact the eastern Kitikmeot starting late Monday afternoon and will continue through to Thursday October 15, 2020. Expected conditions over the region include: Strong easterly winds gusting to 70 km/h, heavy snowfall and blowing snow. Additionally, there is a slight chance of freezing rain over the region. Total snowfall amounts associated with this system remain uncertain at this point in time, but could range between 10-30 cm by Thursday afternoon. As the system approaches and confidence regarding the conditions and impacts increases, the Winter Storm Watches may be upgraded to Winter Storm Warnings. ### Visibility may be suddenly reduced at times in heavy snow. Travel is expected to be hazardous due to reduced visibility in some locations. Winter storm watches are issued when multiple types of severe winter weather are expected to occur together. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NUstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NUStorm.
Expires: 2020-10-12T11:26:41-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2020-10-11T19:27:41-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.2904554484.2020
Area: Taloyoak, Gjoa Haven, Kugaaruk

properties.Title: Frost Advisory In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Frost may damage frost-sensitive fruit trees and vegetable plants. Conditions will be favourable to the formation of frost tonight. ### Frost advisories are issued when temperatures are expected to reach the freezing mark during the growing season, leading to potential damage and destruction to plants and crops. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to QCstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #QCStorm.

properties.Title: Wind Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Strong winds that may cause damage are expected or occurring. A low pressure centre off the west coast of Vancouver Island will move over Victoria late this evening and then move inland overnight. Strong southeast winds currently observed in Victoria will veer to the southwest this evening. As the low crosses near midnight, winds will quickly shift to west 40 to 60 km/h with gusts of 90 km/h near Juca de Fuca Strait. Winds will ease Monday morning as the low departs. ### Damage to buildings, such as to roof shingles and windows, may occur. High winds may toss loose objects or cause tree branches to break. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to BCstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #BCStorm.
Expires: 2020-10-12T15:02:16-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2020-10-11T23:03:16-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.4022804817.2020
Area: Greater Victoria

properties.Title: Snowfall Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Snowfall with total amounts of about 15 cm is expected. 15cm of snow is possible over Pennask and Kootenay Pass summits tonight and Thanksgiving Monday night. A series of fast moving frontal systems will combine with falling freezing levels to give snow over the high elevation mountain passes tonight and tomorrow night. Snow will begin falling late this afternoon and quickly increase in intensity before tapering off in the early morning hours of Monday. 15cm of snowfall is possible for elevations above 1300m before freezing levels rise on Monday. On Monday night the snow levels will lower to near 1100m. Snow will begin falling around midnight, heavy at times, and taper off near noon on Tuesday. An additional 15cm is expected for Pennask Summit and 15-20cm for Kootenay Pass. ### Visibility may be suddenly reduced at times in heavy snow. Weather in the mountains can change suddenly resulting in hazardous driving conditions. Road conditions are available at www.drivebc.ca. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to BCstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #BCStorm.
Expires: 2020-10-12T11:59:30-00:00
